summary: Nicholas B. Stevenson was a Sergeant in the USAF whose recollections were sought by the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) in 1978 as part of their investigation into the JFK assassination. Specifically, the HSCA interviewed Stevenson regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen concerning possible Cuban involvement in the assassination. Stevenson's interview focused on his recollections of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland. The NSA reviewed the report of the interview conducted by Cornwell and Klein and ensured its classification, particularly concerning a facility able to collect the Lisbon-Tangier link. The NSA deemed portions of the interview report as "CONFIDENTIAL, HANDLE VIA COMINT CHANNELS ONLY."
significance: Nicholas B. Stevenson's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his potential knowledge of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland, which was deemed relevant to the HSCA's investigation into allegations of Cuban involvement. His interview and the subsequent classification of portions of the interview report by the NSA suggest that his recollections touched upon sensitive intelligence matters.
